channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Covid: Boris Johnson upbeat about easing lockdown in England on 19 July
item.description: Boris Johnson hopes England will return to as close to the "status quo" as possible on 19 July.

item.title: William and Harry unite to unveil Diana statue at Kensington Palace
item.description: The brothers appear relaxed and at ease as they pay tribute to their mother's "strength and character".

item.title: Trump Organization: Top executive charged with tax crimes
item.description: The ex-president's Trump Organization has been charged with multiple counts of tax fraud in New York.

item.title: Wally Funk, 82, to join Jeff Bezos space flight
item.description: The historic journey will see her become the oldest person to ever fly to space.

item.title: British teenager into Wimbledon third round
item.description: Eighteen-year-old British wildcard Emma Raducanu stuns 2019 French Open finalist Marketa Vondrousova in straight sets to reach the Wimbledon third round.

item.title: Covid-19: PM to set out rules easing and a different Fringe festival
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday evening.

item.title: Global tax overhaul backed by 130 countries
item.description: The OECD, which led the talks, announces that many have backed plans for a 15% minimum corporate tax.

item.title: Canada Lytton: Heatwave record village overwhelmingly burned in wildfire
item.description: The village of Lytton this week recorded the country's highest ever temperature of 49.6C (121.3F).

item.title: Twitter 'troll' to pay Stephen Nolan six-figure sum in damages
item.description: The BBC presenter traced the identity of a person behind defamatory remarks about him.

item.title: Covid: Europe risks new wave, WHO warns
item.description: Cases are up 10% in a week and there are concerns Euro 2020 matches could be super-spreader events.

item.title: Covid: Scientists call for expanded list of symptoms
item.description: Leading scientists say the official list needs to be expanded to make sure cases are not missed.

item.title: Miami building collapse: 'People went to sleep, and then they died'
item.description: Both the mother and grandmother of Pablo Rodríguez were in the building when it fell. Now, he wants answers.

item.title: Euro 2020: The England fan who invited Stormzy round after the Germany game
item.description: Conal O'Leary was watching the football with his mates when Stormzy turned up.

item.title: Los Angeles fireworks explosion: Truck goes up in flames as police seize fireworks
item.description: A truck filled with 2,000kg of fireworks goes up in flames, injuring at least 17 people in Los Angeles.

item.title: Latitude festival-goers 'can jump, dance and hug in safety'
item.description: Latitude's organiser says preventative measures will let people enjoy themselves with confidence.

item.title: Rare white puffin spotted on Scottish island
item.description: The young puffin, spotted on Handa Island, has a lack of pigmentation caused by a genetic condition called leucism.

item.title: Big Ben lands in Manchester for international arts festival
item.description: The huge replica of the London tower is made to look like it has crash landed in Piccadilly Gardens.

item.title: US-Canada heatwave: Visual guide to the causes
item.description: Maps, graphics and charts explaining the Canada and north-west US heatwave, with temperatures at nearly 50C.

item.title: Pets can catch Covid from owners, study suggests
item.description: Pet owners with Covid could infect about 20% of cats and dogs, although most symptoms are mild.

item.title: The teen who created an app to help his sister talk
item.description: Sixteen-year-old Archer Calder developed an app to help his nonverbal sister Della communicate.

item.title: Dennis the Menace: Royal Mail stamps mark 70 years of Beano character
item.description: Royal Mail says the Beano bad boy has entertained generations with his "mischief and mayhem".

item.title: Theatrics or threat: How to handle China's Communist party at 100
item.description: There is much debate about how to deal with the country's authoritarian politics, reports the BBC's John Sudworth.

item.title: Can government ministers use private emails for official work?
item.description: Ex-Health Secretary Matt Hancock and others face criticism over using personal accounts for official business.

item.title: Four reasons why Gap is closing its shops in the UK
item.description: Four reasons why the former High Street favourite is closing its shops in the UK and Ireland.

item.title: Covid: Misleading stat claims more vaccinated people die
item.description: Vaccines reduce the risk of death but do not eliminate it completely.

item.title: King's Lynn: The community shop with a chair for those who 'are not OK'
item.description: A community tells how its local shop has helped it cope during the pandemic and lockdowns.

item.title: Cillian Murphy is sorry for everything in poignant post-apocalyptic film
item.description: All of This Unreal Time, which premieres in Manchester this week, charts a man's existential journey.

item.title: The Amazon sellers who sold up and became millionaires
item.description: Small e-commerce entrepreneurs have thrived in lockdown - now big money wants to buy them out.

item.title: The Easter Island pianist playing for her home's future
item.description: Mahani Teave returned to one of the world's most remote inhabited island to help preserve its culture.

item.title: Curran stars as England comfortably beat Sri Lanka again
item.description: England comfortably beat Sri Lanka again in the second one-day international at The Oval to clinch the series with a game to spare.

item.title: Cavendish wins 32nd Tour de France stage to close within two of Merckx's all-time record
item.description: Mark Cavendish's resurgence continues as he claims his 32nd stage win at the Tour de France to move closer to the all-time record of 34 held by Belgian legend Eddy Merckx.

item.title: Warholm breaks Young's 29-year-old 400m hurdles world record
item.description: Norway's Karsten Warholm runs 46.70 to set a new world record in the 400m hurdles in front of his home crowd at the Diamond League meeting in Oslo.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Roger Federer, Coco Gauff and Daniil Medvedev in day four best bits
item.description: Watch some of the best bits from day four at Wimbledon including an incredible shot by Coco Gauff and a pocket mishap on court two.

item.title: England v Sri Lanka ODI: Sam Curran's five-wicket haul
item.description: Watch Sam Curran take five wickets for 48 runs - and a catch at deep point - at his home ground during England's eight-wicket victory over Sri Lanka in the second ODI at the Oval.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Young Brit Emma Raducanu beats Marketa Vondrousova to reach third round - best shots
item.description: Watch the best shots as 18-year-old British wildcard Emma Raducanu beats Marketa Vondrousova to reach the third round of Wimbledon.

item.title: The EU’s 'vaccine passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: The EU's Digital Covid Certificate is being rolled out across all 27 nations.

item.title: Stamp duty holiday: How much do I have to pay now?
item.description: Stamp duty rules are changing in England and Northern Ireland from 1 July.

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: Employers now have to contribute to the cost of keeping their staff furloughed.

item.title: How many cases are in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the rules about self-isolating, testing and masks in schools?
item.description: The government wants to change the rules which mean entire classes must self-isolate after a positive case.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Millions of people most vulnerable to Covid-19 may be offered a third vaccination in September.

item.title: British Jews' fear and defiance amid record monthly anti-Semitism reports
item.description: Some 460 anti-Semitic incidents were reported to the Community Security Trust from 8 May to 7 June.

item.title: Covid quarantine hotels: Women say they were sexually harassed by guards
item.description: One woman tells the BBC a security guard employed by G4S mimed sex while they were alone in a lift.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?
